questions.text: A 26-year-old woman delivers vaginally at term. Immediately following placental expulsion, her uterus contracts effectively, and there is minimal blood loss. This hemostasis is achieved through the constriction of uterine blood vessels by interlacing smooth muscle fibers that compress them mechanically.Which layer of the uterus is primarily responsible for this physiological control of bleeding after delivery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • As in this case after delivery, hemostasis (control of bleeding) is critical, especially after placental separation. The uterus achieves this through a mechanical method, not primarily by clot formation, but by myometrial contraction(middle layer) often described as the "living ligature" effect.(Option A,Option C,Option D ruled out)
  • 3 layers of uterus
    • Endometrium
    • Myometrium
    • Perimetrium/serosal
  • Layers of myometrium
    • Outer longitudinal
    • Middle interlacing
    • Inner circular
  • The middle layer is the thickest of the three and consists of bundles of muscle separated by connective tissue. There is a tendency for the muscle bundles to interlace, and as the blood vessels which supply the uterus are distributed in the connective tissues, the caliber of the vessels is in part controlled by the contraction of the muscle cells.
  • The purpose of this layer is therefore in part hemostatic. This layer is described as living ligatures of the uterus, and is responsible for control of bleeding in the third stage of labor.

questions.text: Fourchette is present on:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anteriorly, labia minora enclose the clitoristo form the prepuce on the upper surface and the frenulum on its undersurface.
  • Posteriorly, they join to form the fourchette. The fourchette is a thin fold of skin, identified when the labia are separated, and it is often torn during parturition.(Option B,C&D ruled out)

choices.text: Begins at the level of internal OS
Part of vagina which lies above the portio supravaginalis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the portio vaginalis of the cervix is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cervix is divided into upper and lower portions by the vagina's attachment to its outer surface. The upper portion-the Portio supravaginalis-begins at the internal os, which corresponds to the level of the vesicouterine peritoneum.(Option A&B ruled out) The lower cervical portion protrudes into the vagina as the portio vaginalis.
  • The endocervical canal runs through the cervix and connects internal OS with external OS. The cervical surface that radially surrounds the external os is called the Ectocervix.
  • Lining epithelium
    • Endocervix: mucus secreting columnar epithelium
    • Ectocervix: nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium

questions.text: Identify 2 in the following image
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The superolateral angles of the body of the uterus project outwards from the junction of the fundus and body and is called the cornua of the uterus.
  • Three structures are attached at the level of cornua, from anterior to posterior (mnemonic RFO)
    • Round ligament
    • Fallopian tube
    • Ovarian ligament
  • Fallopian tubes are superior most (Fallopian First)
  • This is a laparoscopic view of the uterus, where the ovarian ligament can be identified via its attachment to the ovary.(Option B,C &D ruled out)

choices.text: It is an important step to control postpartum hemorrhage during c-section
To preserve future fertility and menstrual functions U/L ligation done instead of B/L artery ligation.
Internal iliac artery ligation can be tried if uterine artery ligation fails to control PPH
Anatomically uterine artery crosses ureter anteriorly 2 cm lateral to cervix

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is not true regarding uterine artery ligation
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Uterine artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery, from origin it enters → broad ligament → runs downwards and medially → crosses ureter from anteriorly (water under bridge) 2 cm lateral to cervix → gives cervicovaginal branch (supply lower cervix and upper vagina) → from the level of cervix it travels upwards and gives(Option A,C&D ruled out)
    • Arcuate artery: crosses within myometrium and anastomosis in midline supplies OUTER 1/3 of myometrium.
    • Radial artery: originates from right angle of arcuate artery, travels inward to supply INNER 2/3 of myometrium. it divides upon reaching endometrium
    • Basal / straight artery: supplies Basal layer of Endometrium
    • Spiral/ coiled artery: supplies functionalis / superficial layer of endometrium.
  • The ovarian arteryis a direct branch of the aorta and enters the broad ligament through the infundibulopelvic ligament, Ovarian artery along its course supplies fallopian tubes and towards the uterine cornu it forms an anastomosis with the ovarian branch of the uterine artery. This dual uterine blood supply creates a vascular reserve to prevent uterine ischemia if ligation of the uterine or internal iliac artery is performed to control postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: The ovarian end of fallopian tube mucus membrane is lined by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mucous membrane is lined by:
    • Columnar ciliated epithelial cells that are most predominant near the ovarian end of the tube. These cells compose 25% of the mucosal cells,
    • Secretory columnar cells are present at the isthmic segment and compose 60% of epithelial cells,(Option A& D ruled out)
    • Peg cells are found in between the above two cells. They are the variant of secretory cells.(Option B ruled out)
  • Function: The important functions of the tubes are:
    • Transport of the gametes,
    • To facilitate fertilization and survival of zygote through its secretion.

questions.text: Identify structure 'X'
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pubovaginalis is a subdivision of the levator ani that specifically surrounds and supports the vagina.
  • Pubococcygeus extends from pubis to coccyx, forming a broader pelvic floor support but not specific to the vagina.(Option A ruled out)
  • Ischiococcygeus (Coccygeus) lies posteriorly, supporting the sacrum and coccyx, not the vagina.(Option C ruled out)
  • Pubovesical is not a recognized muscle; the term is used for ligaments supporting the bladder.(Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Increase in outlet diameter by 0.2 to 0.5 cm
Reducing diagonal conjugate by 1 to 1.5 cm

questions.text: Dorsal lithotomy position contributes to hasten second stage of labour by which of the following methods
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pelvic joints have a limited degree of mobility but can relax remarkably during pregnancy. At term, the sacroiliac jointcan glide upward. This is greatest in dorsal lithotomy position and may increase the diameter of the outlet by 1.5 to 2.0 cm for delivery. (Option B and C ruled out)
  • Sacroiliac joint mobility also likely aids the McRoberts maneuver to release an obstructed shoulder in cases of shoulder dystocia. These changes may also contribute to the success of the modified squatting position to hasten second-stage labor. Squatting may increase the interspinous diameter and the pelvic outlet diameter.

choices.text: Retroperitoneal structures and enters pelvis behind bifurcation of the common iliac artery.
Cross uterine artery anteriorly to enter ureteric tunnel
It measures 13 cm in length and has diameter of 5 mm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding pelvic ureter:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Total length of ureter is 25cm, Pelvic ureter measures 13-15cm
  • It extends from the crossing of the ureter over the pelvic brim up to its opening into the bladder. It measures about 13 cm in length and has a diameter of 5 mm. Ureter is retroperitoneal of course.
  • The ureter enters the pelvis in front of the bifurcation of the common iliac artery over the sacroiliac joint behind the root of the mesentery on the right side and the apex of the mesosigmoid on the left side.(Option A ruled out)
  • As it courses downwards in contact with the peritoneum, it lies anterior to the internal iliac arteryand behind the ovary and forms the posterior boundary of ovarian fossa.
  • On reaching the ischial spine, it lies over the pelvic floor and as it courses forwards and medially on the base of the broad ligament, it is crossed by the uterine artery anteriorly.(Option B ruled out)
  • It enters into the ureteric tunnel and lies close to the supravaginal part of the cervix, about 5 cm lateralto it. After traversing a short distance on the anterior fornix of the vagina, it courses into the wall of the bladder obliquely for about 2 cm by piercing the lateral angle before it opens into the base of the trigone.

questions.text: Which of the following is present in labia minora
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Structurally, the labia minora are composed of connective tissue with many small vessels, elastin fibers, but very little smooth muscle. Nerve fibers are numerous.
  • The epithelia of the labia minora differ by location. Thinly keratinized stratified squamous epithelium covers the outer surface of each labium. Medial to this line, each labium is covered by squamous epithelium that is nonkeratinized. Labia minora lack hair follicles, eccrine glands, and apocrine glands but have many sebaceous glands.(option A,C &D ruled out)

choices.text: Just above the level of isthmus
In upper part of body of uterus

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for uterine incision during cesarean delivery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Most common site for uterine incision during cesarean is lower segment of uterus.(LSCS)
  • The uterus is pear shaped and consists of two major but unequal parts.
  • The upper, larger portion is the body or corpus, whereas the lower smaller cervix projects into the vagina. The isthmus is the union site of these two.(Option B &C ruled out)
  • It is limited above by the anatomical internal os and below by the histological internal os
  • It is of special obstetrical significance because it forms the lower uterine segment during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female, P6A1L6, all vaginal delivery comes to gynae OPD with complain of something coming out pervaginal on perspeculum examination she has prolapse of pelvic organs which of the following muscle injury occurred during childbirth can predispose to pelvic organ prolapse in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The pelvic diaphragm is broad muscular floor provides substantial support to the pelvic viscera and is composed of
    • coccygeus/ischiococcygeus and
    • levator ani muscles
  • The levator ani muscle contains the
    • Pubococcygeus/ pubovisceral muscle
    • Puborectalis (now it is considered as a part of pubococcygeus muscle)
    • Iliococcygeus muscles.(Option A,B &D ruled out)
  • The pubococcygeus muscle is subdivided based on points of insertion and function. These include the pubovaginalis, puboperinealis, and puboanalis muscles which are inserted in;
    • Pubovaginalis → Vagina
    • Puboperinealis → Perineal body
    • Puboanalis/puborectalis muscles → Anus
  • Evidence suggests that levator ani trauma may predispose women to later pelvic organ prolapse

choices.text: It is a remnant of gubernaculum of testes
It undergoes hypertrophy in pregnancy increasing in both length and diameter
After passing inguinal canal it terminates in lower portion of labia minora
A special artery to the round ligament is called Sampson artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about the round ligament of the uterus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Round ligaments are remnants of gubernaculum (round ligament +ovarian ligament), Each round ligament extends laterally and down into the inguinal canal, through which it passes, to terminate in the upper portion of the ipsilateral labium majus.
  • The artery to the round ligament (SAMPSON ARTERY) is a small branch of the uterine artery and runs within the ligament.
  • In nonpregnant women, the round ligament varies from 3 to 5 mm in diameter and 10 to 12 cm length. During pregnancy, these ligaments hypertrophy and increase appreciably in both length and diameter.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is attached at the cervicovaginal junction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pelvic cellular tissue around the vaginal vault, supravaginal part of the cervix and into the layers of the broad ligament is called parametrium. Condensation occurs especially near the cervicovaginal junctionto form ligaments which extend from the viscera to the pelvic walls on either side.
  • These are
  • Mackenrodt's ligaments/ cardinal ligament,
    • Uterosacral ligaments and
    • Vesicocervical ligaments (fascia).(Option A,B&C ruled out)
  • All these constitute important supports of the uterus to keep it in position.

questions.text: Which of the following structures forms level 1 support for pelvic organs:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mackenrodt’s ligaments and uterosacral ligaments constitute important supports of the uterus to keep it in position importance of these ligaments are:
    • To support the pelvic organs.
    • To form protective sheath for the blood vessels and the terminal part of the ureter.
    • Infection spreads along the track, so formed, outside the pelvis to the perinephric region along the ureter, to the buttock along the gluteal vessels, to the thigh along the external iliac vessels and to the groin along the round ligament.
    • Marked hypertrophy occurs during pregnancy to widen up the spaces.

choices.text: Anterior and posterior walls are opposed together
It looks H shaped on sagittal section
Length of posterior wall is more than length of anterior wall

questions.text: Which of the following is false for vaginal anatomy in a non pregnant state?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vagina has got an anterior, a posterior and two lateral walls. The anterior and posterior walls are opposed together but the lateral walls are comparatively stiffer especially at its middle, as such, it looks "H" shaped on the transverse section.
  • The length of the anterior wall is about 7 cm and that of the posterior wall is about 9 cm(Option A,B &C ruled out).

questions.text: Epidermal inclusion cysts contains:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • After birth-related epithelial trauma and healing, fragments of stratified epitheliumoccasionally is embedded beneath the vaginal surface. Similar to its native tissue, this buried epithelium continues to shed degenerated cells. As a result, epidermal inclusion cysts are formed, which are filled with debris.(Option A,B &C ruled out)

choices.text: Distal fimbrial end of fallopian tube

questions.text: 'X' covers all of the following structures except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • 'X' in diagram is mesosalpinx (part of broad ligament near fallopian tube)
  • FT relation proximally attached to ipsilateral cornua distal end opens into abdominal cavity covered by mesosalpinx (except interstitialportion) fallopian tubes are supplied by branches from uterine and ovarian arteries which runs in mesosalpinx

questions.text: Vagina is supplied by which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The vagina has an abundant vascular supply.
  • →The proximal portion is supplied by the cervical branch of the uterine arteryand by the vaginal artery. (may variably arise from the uterine or inferior vesical artery or directly from the internal iliac artery).
  • →The middle rectal artery: supply to the posterior vaginal wall,
  • →Internal pudendal artery: distal walls.
  • At each level, vessels supplying each side of the vagina course medially across the anterior or posterior vaginal wall and form midline anastomoses.(Option A,B&C ruled out )

questions.text: Which of the following is endodermal in origin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • After the 5th week of fertilization, two Gondal ridges appear in the dorsal aspect of the embryo.
  • These are formed by proliferation of coelomic epithelium and underlying mesodermal cells. (mesodermal origin)
  • COELOMIC CELLS → germinal epithelium and ovarian cortex (granulosa cells)
  • BASAL MESODERM → ovarian stroma
  • The primordial germ cells (oogonia) are formed from cells of the dorsal part of the hindgut (originally yolk sac) , ENDODERMAL origin.
  • Oogonia migrates to ovaries and with the surrounding layer of follicular cells forms primordial follicles.

questions.text: Endometrial cavity is usually formed by?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • As the distal end of the fused müllerian ducts contacts the urogenital sinus, this induces endodermal outgrowths from the sinus, which are termed the sinovaginal bulbs.
  • These bulbs proliferate and fuse to form the vaginal plate, which later resorbs to form the vaginal lumen. Vaginal canalization is generally completed by the 20th week

questions.text: To measure angle of inclination x ray of pelvis done, normally which of the following will be the correct angle degree between the plane of inlet and the front of the body of the 5th lumbar vertebra?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the erect posture, the pelvis is tilted forward. As such, the plane of the inlet makes an angle of about 55° with the horizontaland is called angle of inclination.
  • Another way of measuring the inclination radiographically is to take the angle between the plane of the inlet and the front of the body of the fifth lumbar vertebra. The angle is normally about 135°(Option AB and D ruled out)

choices.text: Between sacral promontory to midpoint of symphysis pubis
Between sacral promontory to upper border of symphysis pubis
Between sacral promontory to lower border of symphysis pubis

questions.text: Which of the following inlet diameter can be measured clinically:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anteroposterior diameter of inlet → true conjugate, anatomical conjugate, conjugate vera): 11cm Between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of symphysis pubisthe true conjugate cannot be estimated directly. Measurement is inferred by subtracting 1.2 cm (½") from the diagonal conjugate
    • Obstetric conjugate: 10 cm Between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to prominent bony projection in the midline on the inner surface of the symphysis pubis. It is the shortest anteroposterior diameter in the anteroposterior plane of the inlet cannot be clinically estimated: diagonal conjugate-1.5-2 cm (¾")
    • Diagonal conjugate: It is the distance between the lower border of symphysis pubisto the midpoint on the sacral promontory. It measures 12 cm (4 ¾"). For practical purposes, if the middle finger fails to reach the promontory or touches it with difficulty, it is likely that the conjugate is adequate for an average size head to pass through.(Option B,C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following does not open in vestibule:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Structures opening in vestibule are
    • Urethra
    • Vaginal orifice and hymen
    • Bartholin duct
    • paraurethral glands/skene's glands
  • Gartner's duct are remnant of wolffian duct, present in broad ligament of uterus

choices.text: Failure of retroversion of gravid uterus

questions.text: A 25 year old primigravida with a 10 week pregnancy comes to an antenatal clinic complaining of an increase in urinary frequency, which of the following can cause increased urinary frequency in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Frequency of micturition is quite a troublesome symptom during 8-12th weeks of pregnancy. It is due to
    • Resting of the bulky uterus on the fundus of the bladder because of exaggerated anteverted position of the uterus,
    • Congestion of the bladder mucosa and
    • Change in maternal osmoregulation causing increased thirst and polyuria.
  • As the uterus straightens up after the 12th week, the symptoms disappear.

questions.text: Which of the following structure expands upto 15 to 20 times during labor
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Isthmus is located between the body of the uterus and cervix (between anatomical and histological OS). It is 0.5 cm in the non pregnant uterus. It expands greatly during pregnancy and labour, large enough to accomodate the fetal head.
  • The uterus which in nonpregnant state weighs about 60 g, with a cavity of 5-10 mL and measures about 7.5 cm in length, at term, weighs 900-1,000 g and measures 35 cm in length.

choices.text: Cervical gland discharge is alkaline in nature and rich in mucoprotein
Vagina has no glands and acidic discharge of cervical glands makes vaginal ph low
Cervical gland secretions contain sodium chloride
None of the above (all are true)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about cervical glands discharge
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Secretion of the cervical glands is alkaline and thick, rich in mucoprotein, fructose and sodium chloride.
  • The vaginal pH, from puberty to menopause, is acidic because of the presence of Döderlein's bacilli which produce lactic acid from the glycogen present in the exfoliated cells. The pH varies with the estrogenic activity and ranges between 4 and 5.

questions.text: With respect to embryological development which of the following structures has dual origin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vagina has dual origin
    • Upper 2/3 → from fused mullerian duct
    • Distal 1/3 → from bilateral sinovaginal bulbs, which are cranial evaginations of the urogenital sinus.
  • Junction of these two is called vaginal plate (forms hymen)(Option A,C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of homologous genital structures is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The epoophoron is derived from mesonephric tubules.The appendix of testis, is a remnant of the Müllerian (paramesonephric) duct, not the mesonephric tubules.

Explanation of other options:

  • Granulosa cells - Seminiferous tubules(Option A):Granulosa cells in females are functionally analogous to Sertoli cells and seminiferous tubules in males.
  • Gartner duct - Vas deferens(Option B):Gartner's duct is a remnant of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct in femalesIn males, the Wolffian duct develops into the vas deferens, epididymis, and seminal vesicles.
  • Paraurethral glands-Prostate glands(Option D): Skene's glands (paraurethral glands) are the female homologues of the prostate gland.

choices.text: It is situated in superficial perineal pouch
Bartholin's gland is about 2 cm and duct measures 0.5 cm
Bartholin duct is lined by columnar epithelium
It secrets mucus which is alkaline in nature

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding bartholin gland?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bartholin's gland is situated in the superficial perineal pouch and measures about 0.5 cm. The duct measures 2 cm. The gland is compound racemose and lined by columnar epithelium.(Option A,Option C ruled out)
  • During sexual excitement, it secretes abundant alkaline mucus which helps in lubrication.(Option D ruled out)
  • The duct opens outside the hymen at the junction of the anterior two-third and posterior one-third in the groove between the hymen and the labium minus.
  • The duct is lined by columnar epithelium except near the opening, where it is lined by stratified squamous epithelium.
  • The Bartholin's gland corresponds to the bulbourethral gland of male.

questions.text: Remnant of wolffian ducts present in broad ligament are all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Each broad ligament contains:
    • Fallopian tube.
    • Uterine and ovarian arteries with their branches, including the anastomotic branches between them and corresponding veins.
    • Nerves and lymphatics from the uterus, Fallopian tube and ovary.
    • Proximal part of the round ligament which raises a peritoneal fold on the anterior leaf.
    • Ovarian ligament which raises a peritoneal fold on the posterior leaf. (Parametrium containing loose areolar tissue and fat. The terminal part of the ureter, uterine artery, paracervical nerve and lymphatic plexus are lying at the base of the broad ligament.)
    • Vestigial structures, such as duct of Gartner, epoophoron, and paroophoron.(Option A,Option B,Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Descent of ovaries usually occurs at?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In early embryos, ovaries are abdominal organs. The ovaries descend during the seventh to ninth months, and at birth, they are situated at the pelvic brim.
  • The cranial part of the genital ridge becomes the infundibulopelvic ligament The part between the ovary and the Müllerian attachment is the ovarian ligament.(Option A,B and D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following muscles doesn't take part in formation of the perineal body?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The perineal body is a fibromuscular mass located in the center of the perineum, where several muscles converge
  • Muscles forming perineal body(Option A,B and C ruled out)
    • Bulbospongiosus
    • Levator ani
    • External anal sphincter
    • Sphincter urethra
    • Superficial transverse Perinei
    • Deep transverse Perinei

Mnemonic: BLESSeD→ ES unpaired rest are paired

choices.text: Ectocervix is rich in nerve endings making it very sensitive to touch, hence manipulation with an instrument can sometimes lead to vasovagal shock
In parous women due to stretching and tearing of skeletal muscles surrounding internal os, external os looks like a slit
Endocervix is lined by high columnar ciliated epithelium , direction of the cilia is towards the external os
Cervix contains only 10% of muscle fibers out of which 30% are in lower 1/3 of cervix

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the cervix?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cervix is insensitive to touch, heat and also when it is grasped by any instrument. The uterus, too, is insensitive to handling and even to incision over its wall. The stroma of the endocervix unlike the ectocervix is rich in nerve endings; hence, manipulation of the cervical canal can cause an unexpected vasovagal attack and severe bradycardia or even cardiac arrest.
  • In nulliparous, the vaginal part of the cervix is conical with the external os looking circular, whereas in parous, it is cylindrical with the external os having bilateral slits. The slit is due to invariable tear of the circular muscles surrounding the external os and gives rise to anterior and posterior lips of the cervix.
  • The endocervix is lined by a single layer of high columnar ciliated epithelium with spindle shaped nuclei lying adjacent to the basement membrane with abundant cytoplasm and mucin. The direction of the cilia is downwards towards the external os
  • Cervix contains mainly collagen and only 10% of muscle fibers. Light microscopic examination reveals 29% muscle fibers in its upper one-third, 18% in the middle one-third and only 6% in the lower one-third, whereas the body of the uterus contains 70% muscle fibers.(Option A,B and D ruled out)

questions.text: Before menarche corpus to cervix ratio is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The relationship between the length of the cervix and that of the body of the uterus varies with age.
  • Before puberty, the corpus to cervix ratio is 1:2.
  • At puberty, this ratio is reversed to 1:2,
  • During the reproductive years, the cervix to corpus ratio may be 1:3 or even 1:4.
  • After menopause (1:1), the whole organ atrophies and the portio vaginalis may eventually disappear.(Option A,B and D ruled out)

questions.text: Mention site for colpocentesis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The posterior vaginal fornix lies in proximity to the peritoneal pouch of Douglas. It is a convenient site for access to the peritoneal cavity
  • colpopuncture, colpocentesis and diagnostic culdoscopy → In the diagnosis of pelvic abscess, ectopic pregnancy and pelvic endometriosis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida patient with and uncomplicated pregnancy undergoes spontaneous labour during second stage of labour she was given right mediolateral episiotomy to enlarge vaginal opening after delivery obstetrician notices extension of episiotomy laceration in mucosa with intact anal sphincter, degree of perineal tear in this patient will be classified as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Classification of Obstetric Anal Sphincter Injury (RCOG-2007)

  • First degree: Injury to perineal skin only
  • Second degree: Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles)but not involving the anal sphincter- episiotomy
  • Third degree: Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex(both external and internal)

3a : <50% of EAS thickness torn

3b : >50% of EAS thickness torn

3c : Both EAS and IAS torn

  • Fourth degree: Injury to perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS) and anal epithelium(Option B,C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following pelvic structures is not developed from urogenital sinus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cloaca (endodermal)is divided by formation of the urorectal septum by the seventh week (7th) and is separated to create the rectum and the urogenital sinus.
  • Urogenital sinus has 3 parts:
    1. The cephalad or vesicle portion → urinary bladder
    2. The middle or pelvic portion → female urethra
    3. The caudal or phallic part → distal 1/3 of vagina (sinovaginal bulb) and the greater vestibular (Bartholin), urethral, and paraurethral (Skene) glands.(Option B ,C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Remnant of paramesonephric duct in male:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Remnants of paramesonephric duct in male
    • Appendix of testis (Hydatid of Morgagni in female)
  • Remnant of mesonephric duct in female
    • Duct of epoophoron
    • Gartner's duct
  • Mesonephric tubules in female
    • Epoophoron
    • Paroophoron

questions.text: Nerve supply of ovaries are derived from the spinal segment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ovaries derive their nerve supply from Sympathetics via renal and aortic plexus and celiac and mesenteric ganglia (derived from T9 T10 spinal segment) which follow the course of the ovarian vessels(Option C and D ruled out).
  • Ovaries are developed from genital ridge (abdominal organ) then descend to the pelvis at 33 weeks of gestation.
  • Ovarian artery is a direct branch of the aorta, other pelvic organs are mainly supplied by the internal iliac artery.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is formed by the obliterated fetal umbilical arteries?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Median umbilical ligament(single) is formed by the urachus, a fibrous fetal remnant that extends from the bladder apex to the umbilicus. Clinically, this ligament may be seen at laparotomy during peritoneal incision as a white, midline, fibrous cord.
  • Medial umbilical ligaments(paired) are formed by the obliterated fetal umbilical arteries.(Option A ,C and D ruled out)
  • Lateral umbilical ligaments(paired) contain the patent inferior epigastric vessels
